awd_titl_txt: Immersd Finite Element Methods for Interface Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
Most of the published research results about immersed finite element
(IFE) methods deal with 2nd order elliptic interface problems. This project 
plans to extend the research on developing and analyzing IFE methods for 
interface problems to more sophisticated partial differential equations such 
as the Stokes system and the linear elasticity system which are of great 
importance in many applications of engineering and sciences. The proposed 
research consists of three key modules which complement each other. The first 
part is to develop new IFE functions and integrate them into modern finite 
element techniques for solving Stokes and linear elasticity interface problems. 
The intent is to find suitable IFE functions locally in interface elements 
that can handle interface jump conditions required by the interface problems 
and other conditions such as the inf-sup stability condition required by the 
finite element formulations to be used. The proposed research will result in 
efficient and robust IFE methods with an emphasis on DG formulations that 
simplify local h-, p-, and hp- refinements on Cartesian meshes. The second 
module is the theoretical analysis of IFEs, starting from their interpolation 
approximation capabilities and deriving error bounds for IFE solutions. The 
challenges are that the traditional analysis techniques have a limited use 
here. For example, using equivalent quotient norm in the scaling argument 
leads to an estimate for IFE interpolation useless for further deriving 
estimate of IFE solution unless it can be shown that the constants in the 
error bounds are independent of the interface. Also, 2D and 3D IFE methods are 
essentially non-confirming methods whose error estimations are often more 
complicated. The third module is about the applications of IFE methods. In 
addition to improving the IFE solver for the particle-in-cell simulator, this 
project will investigate the applications of IFE methods to be developed to 
multi-fluid Stokes flow problems and the multi-material shape/topology 
optimization problems involving the linear elasticity.

The IFE methods to be developed in this project can provide new and efficient 
simulation tools that can use structured/Cartesian meshes to solve challenging 
interface problems involving multi-scale and multi-physics with nontrivial 
interfaces in many areas of engineering and science, including flow problems, 
electromagnetic problems, shape/topology optimization problems, to name just a 
few. This research project will proceed in harmony with the development of IFE 
software packages to verify and support the theory, and address complex and 
realistic problems from a variety of disciplines. This strategy will enable 
theoretical innovation to become practice much more quickly than traditionally 
possible. The proposed research projects will have a great potential to impact 
on numerical simulations in the design/research of ion-propulsion engines for 
interplanetary deep space travel, optimal packaging of electronic devices, 
efficient and better image reconstruction in computer tomography, non-
destructive/non-invasive detection of suspicious materials in security check, 
design of optimal shapes for lighter and stronger structures, and many other 
application areas of great federal interests.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
This project is for the development and analysis of immersed finite element (IFE) methods for using interface-independent (such as Cartesian) meshes to solve interface problems in mathematical modeling of many engineering and science phenomena such as plasma dynamics, geosciences, wave propagation in inhomogeneous and/or moving media, and multi-material topology optimization, to name just a few.

When a quantity is considered in a domain consisting of different materials, the coefficients of the underlying PDEs are discontinuous reflecting different material properties. In addition to the usual boundary condition (and initial condition for time dependent problems), the exact solution to the PDEs is required to satisfy jump conditions mandated by pertinent physics across the interface between different materials; hence, all of these together lead to the so called interface problems. 

Traditional finite element methods solve interface problems with universal polynomials but their mesh has to be made according to material interfaces. IFE methods developed in this project are based on the reversed approach: they use macro finite element functions designed according to specific interface jump conditions instead of simple polynomials so that their mesh can be completely independent of the material interfaces. In many applications, even a simple efficient Cartesian mesh can be used by an IFE method to handle a problem with a complicated interface geometry. IFE methods are therefore competitive for solving problems with challenging issues for traditional finite element methods, for instance, moving interface, thin material layers, and heterogeneous media with very large property variations, etc. On the other hand, IFE methods are closely related with their finite element counterparts because of the consistence of IFE basis functions with standard finite element basis functions. This consistence also makes it easy to adopt IFE methods in applications. 

In this project, we have developed IFE methods for a wide variety of interface problems in many applications of engineering and science, including the widely used 2nd order elliptic interface problem (modeling electric potential, static heat transfer, for example), transient heat transfer interface problems, elasticity interface problems, interface problems for the Stokes flows, and the acoustic wave propagation interface problems. These results clearly demonstrate the great potential for IFE methods to be extended to more sophisticated and more challenging real-world interface problems. Some of these IFE methods are in the traditional Galerkin formulation, but a large portion of them are based on modern discontinuous Galerkin (DG) formulations which facilitates efficient refinement in both polynomial degree and mesh without losing the efficiency of structured meshes used in IFE methods. 

The development of IFE methods also has stimulated the theoretical research in general finite element analysis, especially the analysis for macro finite elements designed to approximate functions with discontinuities across material interfaces inside elements. For example, we have established a group of fundamental estimates for IFE functions, such as the inverse inequalities and the trace inequalities, which further have enabled us to prove the optimal convergence for some IFE methods developed in this project. 
In summary, the funded research has produced IFE methods that are reliable, efficient, and competitive among modern numerical methods for solving real-world interface problems, and it has established some of the related theoretical foundation for IFE methods. Research results generated in this project have been disseminated through 31 peer reviewed journal articles, plus a few more submitted under review, and 67 presentations in conferences, workshops, colloquia, and seminars, in b...

Research results generated in this project have been disseminated through 31 peer reviewed journal articles, plus a few more submitted under review, and 67 presentations in conferences, workshops, colloquia, and seminars, in both USA and abroad.
